Last week, my office hosted the 2025 Human Trafficking Symposium at Eastern Florida State College, partnering with Florida Alliance to End Human Trafficking to bring together advocates, law enforcement leaders, attorneys, and community members to discuss how we can confront one of the most urgent human rights crises of our time.
 
Human trafficking hides in plain sight and remains especially prevalent in Central Florida. Combating this crisis requires that the public be equipped with the knowledge and resources to support law enforcement’s efforts to dismantle trafficking networks and protect victims of this heinous crime.
 
Throughout the symposium, we heard directly from experts including United States Attorney for the Middle District of Florida, Gregory W. Kehoe, on how to recognize the signs of trafficking, how to respond effectively, and how to ensure survivors receive the support they need.
 
When law enforcement, healthcare providers, the transportation industry, and everyday citizens stand together, traffickers cannot hide. The message from our Space Coast community was clear: This crime has no safe harbor here.
